div.head: LIST OF LETTERS COPIED
div.p: *S.G. & E.O.A. Checkland (eds). The Poor Law Report of 1834. Harmondsworth, Penguin 1974: 13

p.hi: The problem of estimating the total number of letters written in mechanically-schooled English

Except for New Romney (I haven’t finished copying all mechanically-schooled letters and noting the totals that parish yet (23/12/11), I haven’t copied all m-s letters in all parishes. Nor have I recorded the total letters in all parishes. I started to do that consistently only 3-4 years ago
If 2005 letters were written in 250 parishes, then 124,590 were written in 15,535 parishes.

But parishes can be divided into rural and urban, especially (to apply the northern word) ‘townships’. Most parishes were rural with small populations, but townships had larger populations, which tended to yield more letters; for example, all parishes I have seen with large collections are urban: Kirkby Lonsdale, New Romney, Beverley and St Margaret’s Rochester.
So, the total number of letters written is likely to be larger than 124,590, but not so large as 1283 (Kirkby Lonsdale) x 15,535 (= 1,993,140)

I need a figure for urban parishes. If I multiply the average number of letters I have copied from, or I know are in the urban parishes by the number of urban parishes, I then have a total which I can add to the total of the average letters I have from rural parishes x number of rural parishes.
1670 letters (not counting 18 documents listed in italics in the parish column)
Total number of parishes where I have copied letters (1996) in mechanically-schooled English:
. Harmondsworth, Penguin 1974: 13) = 1.57% = 127,081 letters for all parishes.
Or, calculating 15,535 x 1283 (= the total number of letters in Kirkby Lonsdale, which seems to have a complete set of letters from 1800 to 1835), 19,931,405 letters in England overall.
Letters of which I have photocopies, which I might use for papers:

div.p: CA, Ann Leeland; WE, Thistlethwaite; DO, Morgan; EX, Brooker; HE, Richard Jones; KE, Ansell, Wiles, Papillon; SO, Denn; SR, Burford.

p.hi: HISTORY OF MY RESEARCH: 29 July 1992 to date

div.p: The first slip I have kept from my Archive visits (CCA & CKS(M) and the BL) is on 29 July 1992 for Dick & Sal. This continued for about two years, when I switched to what I now call mechanically-schooled writing — i.e. letters to overseers. But I had already looked at bills and vouchers by artisans, many of them written in mechanically-schooled English.

REVISION OF GENERAL TRANSCRIPTION POLICY (15 October 2008): Today I decided to record line-breaks in all my transcriptions by a different symbol. Hitherto, I have recorded a line break with ]. But from now on I record it with . I have decided this because 1) my new AppleMac laptop has this symbol, whereas my old AppleMac Performa does not; 2) Ingrid Tieken Boon van Ostade objected to ] on the grounds that has always been used for editorial inserts into a quote. 3) Other transcribers use So far (15/10/08)) I have converted all the Kent files.

p.hi: Listed, but words not counted in the corpus: 5 in Scotland, 12 Luddite letters and all letters classified 6, 7, 8 or 9 in the Data column, which can be found in my handwritten copies.

I list all letters which I count as well- or fully-schooled by CAPITAL LETTERS in the Parish column. Thus, Thomas Woollett in New Romney is classed as well-schooled, but not John Caistor of Dymchurch (also in Maidstone). This is a linguistic classification, and takes no note of social class; thus, Woollett was in a much lower class than Stanhope. 14/9/08

TF (14/9/08): I must think further about the classification of schooling and its relatinship to social class and upbringing. Should I divide the texts into 3 classes—fully-, well- and partly-schooled English? Well- and partly-schooled are defined largely by linguistic criteria, but fully-schooled includes also social criteria, such as membership of the upper classes, because of which the child attended a school which taught Latin and Greek?
200,000 words (1172 letters) reached on 17 Sep 2002, with the three Cobb letters + Mary Godden at the end of 1832 in New Romney, Kent.
225,000 words reached on Monday 2 February 2004 after the visit to the Teesside Archive in Middlesbrough.
250,847 words (1524 letters) reached on 12 August 2004, with 8 letters from Berkshire.
for letters and writings from children at school, see

M – I have a map of the parishes

If the name in the PARISH column is in italics, that item is not counted in the corpus total

div.head: DATA
div.p: first figure equals type of copy I made in the archive, the second shows where it can be found in my handwritten copies.

item.desc: Photo+full Hand, not included in corpus totals.
Photo, not included in corpus totals.
full Hand, not in corpus totals. These are recorded in ITALICS, some are copied into the <TexT> files, others not.
part Hand, not included in corpus totals.

div.p: The figures 1/2 after the name of the county mean: I have visited one Record Office out of 2 in the county.

p.hi: But I have visited at least one R.O. in each English county.

The figures in square brackets after all the other figures in the title line = number of letters written in the months of Nov, Dec, Jan, Feb by partly-schooled writers. Since the period is a quarter if a year it should be no more than 25% of all letters in the list in which the month is recorded. Thus 4/9 = 44% means 4 out of 9 letters with the month recorded were written in the 4 winter months

div.p: IN PARISH: If the name is in capitals, the orthographic units are counted as FULLY-SCHOOLED. The name may be the name of a parish, but it is usually a family name and the letter will be found in the catalogues of private people (HARRIS) or businesses (SEYMOUR), not parishes.
IN SUBJECT: S = schooled; C = “consider/ation”; G =greeting in text (I have not always marked these); T = teacher
If the number I assign to a letter (not the archive reference number) on a printout or in any Data File extracted from this list differs from that in this file, the file number is the latest one.
IN WRITER: If the writer’s name is in bold, she is female

FIGURES ON THE COUNTY TITLE LINE (e.g: (5 - 760; 6 - 934): The first number is the total number of partly-schooled letters I have copied in that Record Office; the second number is the total words in these letters, excluding salutations and valedictions/directions. If there are any letters in fully-schooled English, the totals of letters and words are in the second pair.

All these letters (marked L in DATA) have been copied from Kevin Binfield (ed), Writings of the Luddites. The John Hopkins University Press. 2004. If there is an * after the File No., I have counted the letter in the totals at the top of this file, otherwise not. But I have noted linguistic details in the SPEECH DATA Files. (CH: 1; DB: 1; GL(B) 1; LE: 3; NG 1; YO(L): 5)

Binfield, xxvii: ‘I have chosen to reproduce the documents verbatim and as closely resembling the original manuscripts as typescript will allow so that readers might study the varieties and peculiarities of Luddite grammar, punctuation, and orthography. The principle of verbatim reproduction extends even to the inclusion of intercalations and struck words. I have, however, deviated from the original punctuation in a couple of instances. I have substituted dashes for the marks that resemble something between short underscoring and dashes. Such marks occasionally functioned as periods, commas, or dashes in the handwritten texts and were typically ambiguously placed in their vertical position in each line. I have also substituted periods for short marks that resemble abbreviated hyphens placed at the ends of sentences in the vertical position where a period ordinarily appears. Original authors’ insertions appear in square brackets.’

Binfield, 17: ‘I have discovered, guided by the work of a number of scholars, that Luddite writing is best considered not as a totality but rather as a set of discourses generated under unique local circumstances’. [KB considers three cases: 1) Midlands: Notts, Derbyshire, Staffs, Leics, framework knitters, aka. stockingers; ‘the framework knitting trade, as a recognised public body that openly negotiated with masters through named representatives, provided the Midlands Luddite writers with an established rhetoric and with neatly delineated and commonly desired material goals’ (p.69); 2) West Yorks, Huddersfield, cloth dressers in the woollen indutry, aka. croppers; their discourse was ‘more overtly, though locally, political ... more personally violent’ (p.199); 3) North-west, Lancs, Manchester, cotton weavers; their discourse includes ‘duty’, ‘justice’ and ‘a mingling of constitutional and violent discourses’ (p.70). [Other scholars: Craig Calhoun, The Question of Class Struggle: Social Foundations of Popular Radicalism during the Industrial Revolution. Chicago. University of Chicago Press. 1982. Adrian Randall, Before the Luddites: Custom, Community and Machinery in the English Woollen Industry, 1776-1809. CUP. 1991; John Bohstedt, Riots and Community Politics in England and Wales, 1790-1810.Harvard University Press. 1983.

‘His idea of good German is the idiomatic German of “the mother in the home, the children on the street, the common man in the marketplace”, ...’. David Norton, A History of the English Bible as Literature. CUP. 2000. p. 18. He quotes Luther from Selected Writings of Martin Luther. (ed) Theodore G. Tappert. 4 vols. Philadelphia Fortress. 1967. vol. iv, 181.
WILLIAM TYNDALE (to ‘clerical opponent’)

‘if God spare my life, ere many years I will cause a boy that driveth the plough shall know more of the Scripture than thou dost’. Norton, op. cit. p.19, quoting J. F. Mozley. William Tyndale. London. SPCK. 1937. p. 34.

p.hi: The past is a foreign country. They do things differently there.

div.head: THE COMPLETE LIST

row.cell: Cinde Ass to Sonde the Ront

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: Bare it in my hone brast
I no not wot way to proseed
I am in place but my Wagers
as she as layn in [Her month
G; you well as I am poorly

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: not being come & being much C
you have sant me No relafe
i am a coming home to Line at
wich i shall sand you Money
Liveing with me who am his Unkel
my Children is all Silk Winders
a bloiged; conceder me sth C
baker dont choos to let me get
hoor buirth day; ch’n ave been hill
I yoused to worke at; Dafter
send them hom & fend for self
my Husband ... is gone on Tramp
Mr Mallerd if you pleas to bring
Mr Mallard if you pleas to bring
Mr Mallard if you pleas to bring
Mr Mallard if you pleas to bring
not leave while half past at 3 Ocl
i expets my goods will be seased

p.hi: CAMBRIDGESHIRE: 1/1 (I count Huntingdon (now part of Cambs) separately).
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: hurt by a kick of a horse C
he is wery soft and far a Nuf
I have sent Twise by folks
as for the Little plat thay Due
what is a parish for But to help
i ham shifted into another parish
I had the Cheef of it to pay
the Lord nose; docker; till = while
By the Order of the Magstees
had a Return which has carsd
my wages is taken of two C
my wagers is taken of 2 shillens
in wich i hope consider a nof C
my Husband half pay from the Club
it takes the use of one [Side intirely
in the Stae his is in Naked
to buy a few nuts and oranges
as usual by Mr Macks Van
i have [Read them many times to my
ham not [Settled but i ham in [hopeS
my family [are all most Staved naked

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: so Coind .. att Grate Want C
no coles, no money to pay
eighty fourth year of her Age
not hable to keep a boy like him
money by return of this boat
you must eather pay or I shall
JR still living - very pooley of
letter being sent on is be Half
S: flogged like a Crimanal C
not able to work for to git meat

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: in good Health as it Leaves me
be so cind as to send C
Was More than a Twelvmonth C

wee Shall Be Broyght Back to Graystoc
a girl to wate on hir

she is is in a Decline so
my work it gos down as I do
we will be like to come to

my residence in my own Parish

cell.hi: Famely to be passed to C

row.cell: bad lages, to oles in one
i laid out of my monney
be so Cind, a deal of trb
to no ware you had f’got
laid it all out in things
Crismus, no fire to sit to
hile steel in bad state C

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

i get mi bed ... send me
I hath made an a greement
the far end of this week
i now it is over little

p.hi: Chelmsford: (ES(Ch)/-/-); (144 – 27,893, from 23 parishes; (+1 in 1907 (195) not in corpus)
S in Data = letter in Sokoll, which I too have seen and checked. [38/91 = 41.8%]
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: a few yd of stuf or any thing
hapy to Live with my husban
a pear of Shoeas Some Cloth
a pair of Shoaes for 4 Some
a going to take away paet of
I have no Prospect of coming out
Mary Broocks is in Avery bad
in the 82d Reigment of the Line
iwas very Lame all Last winter
Woman that looks after my legs
the Coales is not Com C
and to carrie us to Quebeak
nescesting to beg the small of
Under Anesety of Riten to you
I hant yearnt not Half A Nuf C
my wish for to go to Ireland
had a Wery havey expence C
putting me to be a sh’maker
she has the ague very Bad
Support my self as a nurse
not bin able to harn a fathen
my half years pay [will be due
Shoes are Nearly of My Feet
have it safe by the Carrer
to have at once leather enough
is a Ship which will sail
get to go to Canterbury C
there is Clothing comes in the
have it by the two months
Being now Sixty Four Years of A
Cloth the children aganst the wi
costomes are getting out to wo
IfI ant to receive the back
& wife are in a middling state
he is eviry on easy a bout it
constant only as work falls out
if i had not have has it did

Daresy you will easely find owt
I hath been; she do sum
Not able to Do what we C
me and my W never broak
Git a nuff to fishreat C
spy: he is Cept up close

I be not abel to do aney
for what you was so good as
bed take from under me C
i will not starve no longe

row.cell: must be done out of Humanity
what hardship whe have bin throw
cannot deny them of the parish
I must a gave my Bead
be shure to send in a fue Dayes
nothing now at the Bazaar to do
pice of Iron falling on my Led
done untell cannot do no longer
I ham Bare foot or I should have

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: if you have a helthey [...] Girl
Go But a Smorl Way towards
we are all very uneasy about you
am under Doctors hands and are
family is very Numors; bring in C

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: find you All in good Health
in arrears at the Shop for meat
Goinge out To A Prentish ship
laid up on the Scarlett fever
the Porson as read my Leatter
Base as to Keep that Bad Woman
make him Pay immeatly or in

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: theas Ear to Lett you know
Wido Cot - I bleue she is
j rot to you mont agoe
as little as Whe can do
get Him Self a old Hors
I Cant Bee able to Send
Percival murder in H of C
I might come by it again
oud; the sider for me to
I will pays it this Sumer
It being my wish, I shd be
to have a Westrey calld C
unable to do any thing C
House rent is very dear C
by the desire of my farther
The Psh of Ry decline takg
be so kinge; to sobsis on
to sea in a oister Boat
put it up in smal Lot
a pair of shoes for Sunday
send has much has I can
tender to serve the Poor H
From a Copy of a Letter
falles As the day is True
I du not Git a nuf a fishing
angery be Caus I have non
I have very much In the want
wages dou not find us C
Step made up his mind not
I shall be obloigd to draw
you can pay down the Sum
I have got one Laid up
wife as been put to bed
got no sho s es upon
see will soot me very well
nothing more to put her on
I am Drove for a hatt
how werry i am of bad of
Having a pauper by the na
Money for to Bye a Lofe of
it is so long since irote
reach you in a good state
to Attend me in my Labor
I do not askout of the way
I have sent by Mr. Brigers
I has Walker when I got ho
boy John gets on very badly
he is doing me great injury
my time is up & ow old I am
i no not wot promest work
my having of a sad misfort
that I may live for 2 mnths
write in behalf of a poor
Man not so well as I hoped
he tell me he is not able
get in Deat at the Shop
do what I can in out Doors
uerrey ell for a Lon time
I have had Nothan to dow
but owing to ill health she
be cause cd not trust to
all that has laid in my power
say we beet her - sarch her
sory to lave my place C
in regard to ... it is what he
nothing but what I stand in
he and myself has been ill
he as got the small pox
I nowshow an was in hope
the times is so very bad
take it off at this time
not be hangry, bread to eat

cell.hi: you new ho was on earth

he is no more [so no more from

Give you and your famley a Blesing C
with a Inflemeson in her knee
to you to put you in mind, to send,
the Lows of our Cuntery hupoulds it
impossible for us to do with pention C
ad=vised her to have it cut off
you scartnly will have got my letter
the told me it must be cut off
my Lanlady is very uneasy for hir rent
under the Necetery of Righting to you
5 Shilins of will Bell to putt on with
all Most Starved this Seavere whether

she is quite dark and Cannot help
I thinke that your beaver is not
the Afflictive hand of ... God C
rendered hir inable to any thing
it is a strang thing to me
made it my lisnes to go
Poor Sister, which you told him
in Clind to leave the toon

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: I have a rite to paye

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: not been so good as your
my master as Turned me of
I am in a Deal of trouble
from the word of A man
keep a House over my head

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: EP Petions you being in great d-
I have given them a lttle Brandy

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: paid in thee corse of 2 or 3

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: my wife Elpless and famyl C
you hos one of the overseer
must be turned over to you

p.hi: WESTMORLAND: 1/1 (See Cumbria and I count Barrow in Lancs)
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: do so oderwise then I have said
no longer ought of My Money
impossible for me to put on
my sester has send you a leter
desires you to be so Cind
BT desiers you Give A Tension
Journey long and I so wake
starved - get any thing to put on
shy at letting him have Provision
C: not powerfull to keep Child
cd not put on - I must Hunger
feard of losen it for work
thir mayday Rent is yet Unpayd
for to set me home with
Old Joseph Desires Me to write
wilst the times is betar C
Ride I am not abel to Walk C
glad to worke at aney price
my ouldest gerl she arns C
they Sould all they few things
indevoured to put on as well as
pay my rent and put me on
they are at the far end Realy
Racked with pain day and Night
like a Child learning to walk
whitch I have not adled mor
there are some halms Given C
Wife is rather in A mending way
we are Just shifted to Rochdale
hard Shiften for a Bitt of Bread
I have Comed to your metins
Me and my Children as ben sick
for the Lordes sak have mrce
will be No Longer Pot of
it will find you in Good helth
Might of had my goods sould
I am sorle opresad by Mr
set By the fir and at Pan ful of
you are very much to Blame
opeing to find you in good
and a Very great Burding to us
for the winter to sirv the walers
if tims wod mend our childer as
adopt me a little more mony C
I hope no a fence in trubling
he is quite A disgrace to me

cell.hi: NB: There are 1283 letters in Kirkby Lonsdale Township Overseers’ Correspondence WPR/19

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: Deare Saly, if I did mary
if he oold a sent me
sais can be a horder mad
famley is large and like to increas
should be wary much oblige to
I am now nearly seventy nine
I hame verey [Hell and My Hise is
7 yr old. Not included in corpus.

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: wen hor could Bot hor his in deed
der brothe .. wen hy coms, but hy
Be for i a [ployed to the over seer
Much as I could do fill there Belleys
i was hiered at upton [statue fair

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: Wee wish you to send to wee
the pechen will Be [pad on frida
me having two small children C
their is one Bell next door
I have Send you tow letters
me Brother Settlem’t or is wife
owin to my old cum plant
A [half hundred white fall on my foot
they got shot of all Money
out of Imploy, his wife lieing in
person I got to Write last
wanted to get of from paying C
been very bad in the Collera
he as gon throo an opperation
she as a poor child outpatiant C
Am done to the last Extremity
i wase laid up to the 11th
I am starving and Family lying
work is so bad to come at that
It is me that sent for relief C
unable to tramp to sek work
as it youst to be wich has put
wife got her bed, child dead C
as had my wife Lying in witch i
hi conseder it but smal thin for C
he had done paying for [St Marys
as nothing to thake to as ther C
oldest beane a Bead of Sikness
Lame that i ham not able to walk
Two Sutes of Cloes and two Paire
Days as a Boy Died on Sunday
dro my money, willen to pay
is living with Im near five munth
you must get a Bed to Bring
as I ham in Great wants
ill this 2 Months, intily of her

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: halth as we are at present
send as Spedy as you can
if I only can rise a pig
to me to Be Very Cross
I dow trutey a Shower you

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: she desireth you to be so

cell.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: you may stopet out of What
There is a pockit Book or Two
Sister / with my loue to you
am grown so feeble and old
hear from as soom a po∫sable
J maid bold to trobell you
J shall be forsed to sell
if you will remit me the
leave them at the Turn pike
my Legs yewles so much I
hif you please to a low me
the loss of my dear wif
It Causeth me to Rite to you

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: near as big in is body
C: any sort of putting on
find him which I have found
Ball his Cast that must take
I heard What the Were on

p.hi: DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT
DATA DATE PARISH SOURCE FILE No. WRITER SUBJECT

row.cell: I ham again forsed to truble
I cannot get out to harn
wish you to take john mager

p.hi: WINTER: Nov, Dec, Jan, Feb. If letters had been written regardless of the season, 484 should have been written in the four winter months. So, 96 more letters (19.8%) were written than is expected from equal distribution.
NB: this is not a proportionate sample of what is in the ROs, but just what I have had the chance to collect.

cell.hi: Chesh, Derbs, Glos, Here, Leic, Lincs, Notts, Northants, Ox, Rut, Shrop, Staffs, War, Worc 14
Beds, Berks, Bucks, Herts, London, Surrey 6
TOTALS OF LETTERS Mechanicals and Grammaticals) IN EACH COUNTY

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: Levene, Alysa, et al. (eds), 2006. Narratives of the Poor in Eighteenth Century Britian. [sic on the title page of Vol 1, eds. Steven King, Thomas Nutt, Alannah Tomkins, Vol 2, ed. Deborah S. Symonds, Vol 3, ed Alysa Levene, Vol 4, ed. Peter King, Vol 5, ed. Lisa Zunshine] London. Pickering and Chatto.
Sokoll, Thomas, (ed.). 2001. Essex Pauper Letters 1731-1837. Oxford. Oxford University Press.
